text: With Neil Armstrong's first step on the moon, America's race with the Russians had come to an end. That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind. Riding on the coattails of the successful Apollo 11 and 12 moon missions, America planned to launch its third manned mission to the lunar surface by April 1970. Unforeseen problems occurred that created a life-and-death situation where the spacecraft and crew were all but lost. The End Hello, I'm Bill Moomey and I portrayed astronaut Will Robinson on TV trying to get home after being lost in space. The success of NASA's space program was the combined result of hundreds of thousands of people working toward a single goal, that of reaching the lunar surface. It was the flight of Apollo 13, more than any other mission before or since, that brought these components to public light. This is the true story of the Apollo 13 mission, as told by some of the unsung heroes who were there and able to cheat death, avoid disaster, bring the astronauts back home safely, and keep the crew from being lost in space. The astronauts for Apollo 13 were chosen a year before launch, commanded by the world's most experienced astronaut James A Lovell Jr. He had already spent nearly 600 hours in space as a crew member on two Gemini flights and Apollo 8, the first round trip to the moon. The other two astronauts accompanying Lovell were both rookies The lunar module pilot was Fred Hayes And the command module pilot was Thomas Ken Mattingly A backup crew trains on the same equipment for the same mission in the event the prime crew cannot go The commander of the backup crew was John Young with Charles Duke as the lunar module pilot and Jack Swigert as the command module pilot. Few people realize how many hundreds of hours these astronauts and flight controllers spent in training and simulating mission activities. Every action and movement during their mission were carefully planned and well thought out, which were the real secrets to the successes of the Apollo program. The simulations that we ran were very high fidelity, they were very much like a real flight, you know, sitting in the control center, we couldn't tell the difference between whether it was a simulation or a real flight, it looked exactly the same. In the simulation people could throw faults into the system and they'd test us to see if we handled them correctly. Thousands of problems and failures had been considered, documented, and simulated throughout the history of the space program. These training sessions formed the basis of the rules each mission followed. Mission rules were all written to give you time to deal with issues that you didn't realise were going to happen, and not very many times did anything happen that we didn't have a pre-planned operation for. Sometimes they were disparate, or sometimes not directly associated with each other as they had happened in the simulation but the flight controllers at that point in time in Apollo were very well trained I believe to handle most anything that could happen. We tried to cover at best what we thought were all the thousands of credible failures that could happen both the spacecraft and the mission. There were some always some people offline including myself but in some key people that worked for me that And they would sit around at night and dream up worst case contingencies and what ifs and draw out solutions on the back of a napkin, kind of an arrangement, that weren't subjected to formal training. So there was always a lot of, what if this really does happen. The crewmen tried to play it out as close as possible to what was really happening. That is they played it like it was real. Even the far out cases where it was almost too difficult to survive, they played them all the way through. That doesn't mean we didn't crash on the moon sometime. It was not our intention to practice for disaster. I mean you don't need to do that But we would give them situations and in any of these situations you might do the wrong thing the first time You know and then you go back and think about what you would do and then change your response and Get better at it Singulation people would hit us with the failure and we'd handle it They hit us with another and hit us and they would just finally they load us up so heavy that they knew They could finally break us if they just kept working at it and so we had some good natured of ribbing quite often between us where we would say, Look, get realistic. You know, all those failures aren't going to happen. In the process of training, we crashed many times into the medium. Other times we'd get very nervous about what was happening with the guidance system, and we'd abort unnecessarily to the point where we really started losing confidence in our own ability as controllers, our ability as a team. The simulation team has to be able to defend their selection of a failure. That's about the only thing they have to answer for. They can be merciless in their scripting, they do it in real time. They take great delight and they're really good. They are just superb and as a result we all learned a great deal about how to deal with the systems and how they work and made our rules better because we'd try things that Worse than didn't. Lovell, Hayes, and Mattingly spent every minute of every day for over a year in simulators and training for this specific mission. They were ready and prepared to meet their destiny in space. Their spacecraft was by far the most complex piece of machinery ever sent into space. The Saturn V rocket booster had three stages and was over 40 stories high. Sitting on top of this rocket were the command, service, and lunar modules. The command module capsule, shown here in deep blue and named Odyssey, was where the crew were to stay for their journey. The service module, shown here in silver and red, was where the propulsion system and compressed air were located. The lunar module that was to take Lovell and Hayes to the moon's surface, named Aquarius, would be held inside the top of the third stage rocket booster until after launch. Each and every one of the six million parts making up this spacecraft had to be tested and retested, but the Apollo 13 spacecraft would be ready to fulfill its task on schedule. I'd have been on that flight, I'd have started worrying early on. I mean, like, it was Apollo 13. There had never been a 13 in either the Mercury-Gemini programs. I mean, it was going to be the first spacecraft that was called 13. And I can tell you, in the Army, in the military, I mean, like, there's a superstition about numbers in 13. And Marilyn Lovell says that she was superstitious about it, you know. I mean, she didn't like the idea of it being called 13. but Jim Lovell, of course, had no problem with it. I mean, like, he wanted to go, you know. I mean, he could have cared less what you called it. Just a month before launch, the Apollo 13 Jinx appeared for the first time during a test of the spacecraft's two liquid oxygen tanks that supplied the water, electricity, and breathable oxygen for the spacecraft. The tanks were supposed to be filled and emptied as a routine check for leaks in the tanks or lines. We'd had a tanking test on the spacecraft on the ground. And when they went to detank, they were unable to get one of the oxygen tanks to dump its load. And they decided to use the heaters in the tank to boil the oxygen off. And we'd had some fairly lengthy discussions with the engineers about it. I was convinced that our engineering team had a good story. They understood what they were doing and procedures were sound and I told Jim he didn't need to worry about it. Unknown to the engineers or crew, an electrical current overload in one of the oxygen tanks shorted out the heater switch and fused the circuit breaker shut. This malfunction was not identified and turned the tank into a bomb. Only a week before launch, the Apollo 13 jinx appeared again and threw the entire mission into a turmoil. The problem initially was I was so disappointed that I'd call all that. I had the measles, you know, a week before the liftoff and exposed the whole crew to it. Ken hadn't had the measles. And so it was a big mess just because I had the three-day measles. Sending Mattingly to the moon with the possibility he might come down with the measles was simply unthinkable for NASA. Their only choices were to either scrub the mission entirely, an equally unthinkable prospect, or to replace Mattingly with his backup counterpart, Jack Swigert. Mixing and matching crews after several months of training together was never done before, but was the only option left open to NASA. So only two days before the flight, Mattingly was removed and replaced by Swigert. This was the only time in the history of the space program that one Prime crew member was replaced with a backup after they had begun their training. Having concentrated seven days a week, 24 hours a day on an event It's suddenly denied for what you feel is an unreasonable reason, even though intellectually, you know that it's a sound decision. Emotionally, you feel like you've been cheated from something important. I don't think from our viewpoint, at least, that taking TK out of that seat and putting in Swigert was a big impact. We didn't notice that much difference. The backup crews have trained very much, like the prime crews, not as much, but obviously they were ready to go. Well, it was a testimony to our training that they could change out a person in that crew two days before launch and still the crew could function. The Apollo 11 and 12 moon missions were so successful that the Apollo missions began to take on a routine nature, creating a sense of complacency in the public and media. When launch day came for Apollo 13 on April 11, 1970, the launch itself was met with distinct public apathy and media indifference. I think something like seven million people showed up to watch the Apollo 11 blast-off. Apollo 12, a few months later, I think there were two million people showed up, stood on the beach, watched the blast-off. By the time he got to Apollo 13, it was down to about 200,000. And the network didn't even cover the telecast. At exactly 1313 military time in Houston, the Apollo 13 mission began with the Saturn V rocket lifting the spacecraft toward orbit. On the way up on the booster, we happened to lose the center engine on the second stage about two minutes early. It just shut down due to high vibrations. And for that moment, we thought that this was the crisis of this particular flight, because most space flights, with the exception perhaps of 8, usually had something go wrong with them. But we had enough fuel, we had enough power and enough engine power to get us into Earth orbit and then push us on to the moon. Once the spacecraft left Earth's orbit, the Command and Service modules separated from the 3rd Stage Rocket Booster and turned around to dock up with the Lunar Module. After docking was completed, Springs ejected the Lunar, Command and Service Modules from the Saturn rocket and the crew flew to the moon in this arrangement. ... In Apollo 13 as in all flights that I've ever had anything to do with you always seem to have some malfunctions that take place. In Apollo 13 there were several but I don't think they were earth shaking or unexpected standpoint of problems. I'd say particularly on Apollo 13, most things were pretty routine and had gone reasonably and we were looking forward to the third landing on the moon. However, none of the networks even bothered to broadcast it. This is the crew of Apollo 15, guys. Everybody there, a nice evening and we're just about ready to close out our inspection of Aquarius and good back for a pleasant evening at Odyssey. Good night. Mission Control noticed a slight pressure drop in one of the oxygen tanks and instructed Swigert to turn on the heaters and stir the tank up. Unknown to the crew at the time, an electrical short circuit sparked a fire in the oxygen tank's protective covering, causing the tank to explode with such force that it blew a huge panel off the service module. The explosion also ruptured the backup oxygen tank. We've got a problem here. Can I pay again, please? Houston, we've had a problem. And I heard a hissed bang. The spacecraft rocked back and forth. The jet started to fire to stabilize the spacecraft. I looked up at Fred, and Fred looked down at me, and I knew that Fred didn't know what caused his bang. Then I looked over at our third companion, Jack Swigert. He was over there in the left seat, and his eyes were as wide as saucer. Our life support console and its operator noticed that we're beginning to see the pressure decrease in oxygen in the service module and for a time period we went through the normal steps to try to figure out what that situation might be. was it some problem with instrumentation, even though the crew had definitely heard something occur? And more importantly, is it something where the procedures we had could isolate that problem? And we started seeing so many signatures. There were all kinds of strange electrical signatures, things in the fuel cells and all over where it didn't match any of the kinds of symptoms that we had been trained to look for. And we felt that we really had run into another one of the bizarre instrumentation phases. Looking at the instruments that told me the condition of two huge liquid oxygen tanks that we had way back in the service module, on the quantity gauge of one, it read zero. And on the quantity gauge of the other, I could see the needle slowly go down. Okay, Houston, I'm John. I tried to reset that fuel cell 1 and 3, both showing gray flags, but they're both showing zip on the flows. Арnie Aldridge called me. And the question and the dialogue was kind of like this between Arnie and I. He says, John, there's been some kind of an anomaly here and the guys in the Mission Control Team were chasing it because it seems to be a bunch of unrelated things. it must be some kind of problem with the data relay of all the measurements from the spacecraft. Initially, no one at mission control could believe that there was a complete structural failure of the spacecraft, a situation that was never even simulated before. It's so I asked him, I said, what are you reading some parameters? So I asked him to call up some ECON displays and he read me some parameters and I said well read me some more and I said no that's not, that's not an incantation failure. It may be missing more and I remember summarizing to him at the end of that conversation, Arnie, I don't know what problem you're chasing out there but it's a real problem, it's not an incantation problem. That problem is real. You have a real problem. Obviously I'll be right there. I went past Jack, looked out the side window and I could see escaping at a high rate of speed a gaseous substance from the rear end of my spacecraft and very shortly we'd be completely out of oxygen and we'd be completely out of electrical power and when that occurred because we gimbled our maneuvering engine by means of electricity we would lose our propulsion system what started out as a routine milk run to the moon was now turning out to be the single greatest test of NASA's creative ability to solve complex problems on a real-time scale to bring the crew back alive. The mission was lost, and these astronauts were in a broken down spacecraft, almost 200,000 miles from Earth, going in the wrong direction, and had no idea how or if they were going to come home. On the night of April 13th, I had just come into the control center maybe half hour ahead of time. And I was getting ready to go on shift. My team was going on to the shift takeover from Gene's team, Gene Kranz's team. We needed time to think, we needed time to establish a plan. We needed time to figure out what was going wrong, what had gone wrong, and then we needed time to figure out what we were going to do about it. Basically, the first activity we had was to buy time. I think most of the team operated with confidence that we were going to be able to pull it off, if it was salvageable at all. I would have to say that probably each one of us in our own heart of hearts, at some point during the events after the blow up and before we got stabilized, probably had a little bit of a sinking feeling as to how this thing was going to turn out. Some people at Mission Control wanted the spacecraft to turn around and return to Earth immediately. But Kranz and Lonnie argued that they couldn't depend on the spacecraft's propulsion system and needed to build a rescue plan in the simulators. I mean, they had never simulated that many system failures. I mean, the electrical system totally failed. The oxygen system totally failed. I mean, those kind of things weren't supposed to happen. With only 15 minutes of electricity left in the command module, Mission Control had to accept the fact that the command and service modules were dying and would have to be shut down completely. There was never any plans or even procedures to totally turn it completely off, dead, in orbit or to activate it from a dead state in orbit. That was not a set of procedures that we either had or thought we needed. Because it was a philosophical hurdle as well as a technical hurdle in this room. With the command module as good as dead, mission control decided that their only option was to move the crew into the lunar module. In the course of the evening, you know, I guess one way to think of ourselves is we were a little bit of a, almost a mash hospital in a sense in that we had to stabilize the situation and shut the command module down as gracefully as we could and get the crew moved over and powered up in the lunar module and then do a lot of things with it that we had not planned for or trained for and all that time not make any bad mistakes that would compromise how things might turn out at the end of the mission. objetient. Now, it would be called on to support all three crew members for at least the four or five day flight back to Earth. Everyone at Mission Control, including the flight crew, did some mental calculations of what power and consumables remained in the spacecraft and came to the conclusion that the crew would be lost. Since all of the systems of the spacecraft would have to be pushed beyond the outer limits of their specifications, all of the contractors were also contacted for their expert opinions on what could be done to help rescue the crew. while most of america slept control rooms around the country hosted crews of bleary eyed technicians working on computers slide rules and simulators to come to a solution to this crisis people in bethpage in new york that built the linear module swung into action many of the people that supported them by building components that went into that. The first immediate challenge facing mission control was to change the trajectory of the spacecraft using the lunar module engines. In the case of Apollo 13, because of the landing site and the lighting conditions that were desired, we actually diverted from the free return trajectory—that is, free return to the earth after swinging around the moon—and we were on a trajectory which, had we not done any more burns, would never have returned anywhere near the vicinity of the earth. And we knew that we had to perform some kind of a propulsion maneuver with one of the rocket systems in order to correct the trajectory and get ourselves swinging around the moon, but then coming back towards the Earth approximately in an entry corridor. After this burn put the spacecraft on the correct flight path, debates immediately began to rage in mission control. The directors and management split into two separate factions on just how quickly to bring the crew home. One group wanted to jettison the useless service module to lighten the spacecraft and burn the lunar module's engine at maximum as it rounded the far side of the moon, bringing the spacecraft back to Earth as soon as possible. The other group argued if the service module was jettisoned, the command module's heat shield would be exposed to at least four days of the ultimate cold of space. They pushed to leave the service module attached and take a more conservative but longer return to Earth. We had managers who listened to the technical inputs of the members of the team, and myself and Lonnie and a couple of the other flight directors. Said, hey the way to do it is to take the long road home because we have the confidence we can stretch the limb. And again, what we have to do is we have to establish a strategy for coming home. We don't want to force ourselves into decisions early in the game. We've got this limb spacecraft. We've learned how to use it as a lifeboat. We ought to continue to use it out of lifeboat. The burn we decided on was to, as we passed the moon's closest point of approach, we call that parascythian two hours later we decided to do a burn and so we decided to take the easier or the more conservative approach and get them back get them back where we had a carrier and get them back at 142 hours. About 6 hours after the initial explosion the final details for the parascythian burn were being worked out by the backup astronauts in simulators and were ready to be radioed up to Lovell. Their exhaled breath was creating a buildup of carbon dioxide. A chemical in canisters normally filtered out the carbon dioxide, but the system in the lunar module was becoming dangerously overburdened. The command module had several large square canisters, but the lunar module had only two small round ones. When the command module was shut down, its circulation system also shut down. So our flight controllers took a very ingenious way to flow power backwards from the lunar module to charge. We had a battery charger on the board of the command and service module. Of course, with the fuel cells gone and the oxygen tank gone, there was no way to power the battery charger. But they came up with an ingenious way to manipulate hundreds of circuit breakers. We should have kept that checklist of back-flow power from the lunar module to the command module. We finally ended up with a complete set of procedures which we then sent over to the simulator and gave it to a cold crew, because it wouldn't do any good for me to go run the procedure since I had essentially put it together. I would do it right anyhow without the language being correct. So we gave it to a cold crew that had not had anything to do with it in hopes of catching any ambiguous phrasing or things that would be difficult. We got concerned about that. So we ran into the simulator. And sure enough, I mean, if we were gonna come within 10 degrees of that critical maneuver. So we talked flight control into abandoning that maneuver, and let's just stand with a safe attitude, and when we separate, then we will reorient and get things done, and that's what we did. The astronauts on the ground were invaluable, in this period, they were very knowledgeable about exactly what was happening upstairs, but they also were enabled to do that because of the great simulation capability, which I think will forever be one of the unsung major, major reasons we had the successes that we did. Even when things worked right, they were invaluable. But when things went wrong, they were really just absolutely necessary. The crew jettisoned the service module first, then tried to swing around to get a look at the damage caused by the oxygen tank explosion. And there's one all side of that thing in this one. Is that right? Just before reentry into the Earth's upper atmosphere, the lunar module was jettisoned. Okay, copy that. Farewell, Aquarius. Thank you. I think we felt reasonably comfortable that once we got the command module separated from all this excess hardware now that it was going to work okay. Because we had checked those systems out, and we had brought the systems back online. We had had all the systems working about an hour before we got ready to do that separation work. And I think we were reasonably satisfied it was going to work okay. Everyone realized, however, that there could have been damage to the heat shield, parachutes, or any of a dozen other potential problems resulting in the loss of the capsule and crew. All those things were on our mind, but not very high level in the sense that for the most part there are things we couldn't do anything about. They were of what we would call a hand-wringing type, and if we couldn't do anything about them and we couldn't figure out any way if there weren't any defenses against their implications, we generally walked past it and said, well, if it is, so be it, if it's not, we'll be okay. When the heat shield of a spacecraft traveling 20,000 miles per hour first comes into contact with the upper atmosphere, it becomes red hot from the friction. The superheated air around the capsule creates a radio blackout for several minutes. Based on prior missions, the blackout time had been calculated down to the second. In the case of Apollo 13, I mean, they were supposed to be, and say it's three minutes and 10 seconds in blackout. And so they're watching the clock and it gets down to three minutes and 10 seconds and they wait to hear from them. They don't hear anything. I mean, oh God, did the parachutes work? Because they'd been frozen out there in outer space all this time. Maybe the parachutes didn't work. Maybe the heat shield didn't work. All these things that maybe didn't work. And it's three minutes and 30 seconds and three minutes and 40 seconds. I think it went past four minutes. You could have heard of 10 drop. I mean, it was just quiet as it could be. Only the Capcom, every once in a while, I call him, Apollo 13, this is Houston. Apollo 13 is Houston, do you read? Finally, about four, about four and a half minutes, total blackout. I think it was Jack. It may have been Jim, but it may have been Jack. Hello, Houston, this is 13, how do you read? Almost casually. The report that a RIA-4 aircraft has acquisition of signal. The re-entry was clearly the most widely watched worldwide event in the history of television, and everyone certainly expressed a simultaneous sigh of relief, then cheer as they saw the parachutes come out and drop the capsule into the ocean. We opened the doors of this room, and these hundreds of people would come into the room, all of whom had one little piece of this mission, but without whom we couldn't have done this mission. There was just a feeling of togetherness, of bond, unity, accomplishment. It was just the most marvelous feelings in my entire life existed in this room. Perhaps the most important aspects of this particular mission were the overall implications of this rescue. I think a real tribute to the way NASA does business, not one thing that we did had to be invented from scratch. I'm convinced that virtually everything that we did had been done in a simulation somewhere, some time prior to that mission. The only thing we did was to package them in a different order. I think the great thing about Apollo 13 is that it really shows that it's not all about technology. You know, I mean, like even when all the gadgets fail, these people can still pull it out. You know, I mean, or they did in that case. I mean, it just shows how, what the level of ingenuity is. You know, I mean, just the determination of the people involved to make it work, to rescue their friends. Fundamentally, I mean, these were all their friends that are out there lost in space. And if they were going to get them back, they were determined to get them back, they weren't going to accept no for an answer, and they pulled it off. We went into space as a country in response to a major challenge. We went there to learn about space. We went there to learn about ourselves. We went there to explore. We went there to be able to go out beyond that. In that context, I would view that in terms of opening up space, in terms of being confident in our ability to do things, Apollo 13 was really a tremendous success. None of the three crew members of Apollo 13 went into space again. Jim Lovell had already promised his wife that this was to have been his last mission. Jack Swigert went into politics and was elected as a congressman but died of cancer before taking office. Fred Hayes went on to do development work on the space shuttle, but retired before its first flight. T.K. Mattingly, who was replaced for this mission, eventually did go to the moon on Apollo 16, along with John Young and Charles Duke. Mattingly was also the commander of two space shuttle missions, becoming a veteran astronaut himself. Perhaps the Apollo 13 mission showed the world beyond any shadow of a doubt just how much could be accomplished accomplished when the success of a mission was the only thing that mattered. Where thousands of people contributed anonymously towards achieving that single goal and taking pride in the team effort without any self-serving attention given to any one individual. No matter what the challenge, mankind has the ability to rise to the occasion. you And I'll see you next time.

segments.text: With Neil Armstrong's first step on the moon, America's race with the Russians had come
to an end.
That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind.
Riding on the coattails of the successful Apollo 11 and 12 moon missions, America planned
to launch its third manned mission to the lunar surface by April 1970.
Unforeseen problems occurred that created a life-and-death situation
where the spacecraft and crew were all but lost.
The End
Hello, I'm Bill Moomey and I portrayed astronaut Will Robinson on TV
trying to get home after being lost in space.
The success of NASA's space program was the combined result of hundreds of thousands of
people working toward a single goal, that of reaching the lunar surface.
It was the flight of Apollo 13, more than any other mission before or since, that brought
these components to public light.
This is the true story of the Apollo 13 mission, as told by some of the unsung heroes who were
there and able to cheat death, avoid disaster, bring the astronauts back home safely, and
keep the crew from being lost in space.
The astronauts for Apollo 13 were chosen a year before launch, commanded by the
world's most experienced astronaut James A Lovell Jr. He had already spent
nearly 600 hours in space as a crew member on two Gemini flights and Apollo
8, the first round trip to the moon.
The other two astronauts accompanying Lovell were both rookies
The lunar module pilot was Fred Hayes
And the command module pilot was Thomas Ken Mattingly
A backup crew trains on the same equipment
for the same mission
in the event the prime crew cannot go
The commander of the backup crew was John Young
with Charles Duke as the lunar module pilot and Jack Swigert as the command module pilot.
Few people realize how many hundreds of hours these astronauts and flight controllers spent
in training and simulating mission activities.
Every action and movement during their mission were carefully planned and well thought out,
which were the real secrets to the successes of the Apollo program.
The simulations that we ran were very high fidelity, they were very much like a real
flight, you know, sitting in the control center, we couldn't tell the difference between whether
it was a simulation or a real flight, it looked exactly the same.
In the simulation people could throw faults into the system and they'd test us to see
if we handled them correctly.
Thousands of problems and failures had been considered, documented, and simulated throughout
the history of the space program. These training sessions formed the basis of the rules each
mission followed. Mission rules were all written to give you time to deal with issues that you
didn't realise were going to happen, and not very many times did anything happen
that we didn't have a pre-planned operation for. Sometimes they were disparate, or sometimes not
directly associated with each other as they had happened in the simulation but
the flight controllers at that point in time in Apollo were very well trained I
believe to handle most anything that could happen. We tried to cover
at best what we thought were all the thousands of credible failures that
could happen both the spacecraft and the mission. There were some always some
people offline including myself but in some key people that worked for me that
And they would sit around at night and dream up worst case contingencies and what ifs and
draw out solutions on the back of a napkin, kind of an arrangement, that weren't subjected
to formal training.
So there was always a lot of, what if this really does happen.
The crewmen tried to play it out as close as possible to what was really happening.
That is they played it like it was real.
Even the far out cases where it was almost too difficult to survive, they played them
all the way through.
That doesn't mean we didn't crash on the moon sometime.
It was not our intention to practice for disaster. I mean you don't need to do that
But we would give them situations and in any of these situations you might do the wrong thing the first time
You know and then you go back and think about what you would do and then change your response and
Get better at it
Singulation people would hit us with the failure and we'd handle it
They hit us with another and hit us and they would just finally they load us up so heavy that they knew
They could finally break us if they just kept working at it and so we had some good natured
of ribbing quite often between us where we would say,
Look, get realistic.
You know, all those failures aren't going to happen.
In the process of training, we crashed many times into the medium.
Other times we'd get very nervous about what was happening
with the guidance system, and we'd abort unnecessarily
to the point where we really started losing confidence
in our own ability as controllers, our ability as a team.
The simulation team has to be able to defend their selection of a failure.
That's about the only thing they have to answer for.
They can be merciless in their scripting, they do it in real time.
They take great delight and they're really good.
They are just superb and as a result we all learned a great deal about how to deal with
the systems and how they work and made our rules better because we'd try things that
Worse than didn't.
Lovell, Hayes, and Mattingly spent every minute of every day
for over a year in simulators and training for this specific mission.
They were ready and prepared to meet their destiny in space.
Their spacecraft was by far the most complex piece of machinery
ever sent into space.
The Saturn V rocket booster had three stages and was over 40 stories high.
Sitting on top of this rocket were the command, service, and lunar modules.
The command module capsule, shown here in deep blue and named Odyssey,
was where the crew were to stay for their journey.
The service module, shown here in silver and red,
was where the propulsion system
and compressed air were located.
The lunar module that was to take Lovell and Hayes
to the moon's surface, named Aquarius,
would be held inside the top of the third stage rocket booster
until after launch.
Each and every one of the six million parts
making up this spacecraft
had to be tested and retested,
but the Apollo 13 spacecraft would be ready
to fulfill its task on schedule.
I'd have been on that flight, I'd have started worrying early on.
I mean, like, it was Apollo 13.
There had never been a 13 in either the Mercury-Gemini programs.
I mean, it was going to be the first spacecraft that was called 13.
And I can tell you, in the Army, in the military, I mean, like, there's a superstition about numbers in 13.
And Marilyn Lovell says that she was superstitious about it, you know.
I mean, she didn't like the idea of it being called 13.
but Jim Lovell, of course, had no problem with it.
I mean, like, he wanted to go, you know.
I mean, he could have cared less what you called it.
Just a month before launch,
the Apollo 13 Jinx appeared for the first time
during a test of the spacecraft's two liquid oxygen tanks
that supplied the water, electricity,
and breathable oxygen for the spacecraft.
The tanks were supposed to be filled and emptied
as a routine check for leaks in the tanks or lines.
We'd had a tanking test on the spacecraft on the ground.
And when they went to detank,
they were unable to get one of the oxygen tanks to dump its load.
And they decided to use the heaters in the tank to boil the oxygen off.
And we'd had some fairly lengthy discussions with the engineers about it.
I was convinced that our engineering team had a good story.
They understood what they were doing and procedures were sound and I told Jim he didn't need to worry about it.
Unknown to the engineers or crew, an electrical current overload in one of the oxygen tanks shorted out the heater switch and fused the circuit breaker shut.
This malfunction was not identified and turned the tank into a bomb.
Only a week before launch, the Apollo 13 jinx appeared again and threw the entire mission into a turmoil.
The problem initially was I was so disappointed that I'd call all that.
I had the measles, you know, a week before the liftoff and exposed the whole crew to it.
Ken hadn't had the measles. And so it was a big mess just because I had the three-day measles.
Sending Mattingly to the moon with the possibility he might come down with the measles was simply
unthinkable for NASA. Their only choices were to either scrub the mission entirely, an equally
unthinkable prospect, or to replace Mattingly with his backup counterpart, Jack Swigert.
Mixing and matching crews after several months of training together was never done before,
but was the only option left open to NASA.
So only two days before the flight,
Mattingly was removed and replaced by Swigert.
This was the only time in the history of the space program
that one Prime crew member was replaced with a backup
after they had begun their training.
Having concentrated seven days a week,
24 hours a day on an event
It's suddenly denied for what you feel is an unreasonable reason, even though intellectually,
you know that it's a sound decision.
Emotionally, you feel like you've been cheated from something important.
I don't think from our viewpoint, at least, that taking TK out of that seat and putting
in Swigert was a big impact.
We didn't notice that much difference.
The backup crews have trained very much,
like the prime crews, not as much,
but obviously they were ready to go.
Well, it was a testimony to our training
that they could change out a person in that crew
two days before launch and still the crew could function.
The Apollo 11 and 12 moon missions were so successful
that the Apollo missions began to take on a routine nature,
creating a sense of complacency in the public and media.
When launch day came for Apollo 13 on April 11, 1970,
the launch itself was met with distinct public apathy and media indifference.
I think something like seven million people showed up to watch the Apollo 11 blast-off.
Apollo 12, a few months later, I think there were two million people showed up,
stood on the beach, watched the blast-off.
By the time he got to Apollo 13, it was down to about 200,000.
And the network didn't even cover the telecast.
At exactly 1313 military time in Houston,
the Apollo 13 mission began with the Saturn V rocket
lifting the spacecraft toward orbit.
On the way up on the booster, we happened to lose the center engine on the second stage
about two minutes early.
It just shut down due to high vibrations.
And for that moment, we thought that this was the crisis of this particular flight,
because most space flights, with the exception perhaps of 8, usually had something go wrong with them.
But we had enough fuel, we had enough power and enough engine power
to get us into Earth orbit and then push us on to the moon.
Once the spacecraft left Earth's orbit, the Command and Service modules separated from
the 3rd Stage Rocket Booster and turned around to dock up with the Lunar Module.
After docking was completed, Springs ejected the Lunar, Command and Service Modules from
the Saturn rocket and the crew flew to the moon in this arrangement.
... In Apollo 13 as in all flights that I've ever had anything to do with you always seem
to have some malfunctions that take place.
In Apollo 13 there were several but I don't think they were earth shaking or unexpected
standpoint of problems.
I'd say particularly on Apollo 13, most things were pretty routine and had gone reasonably
and we were looking forward to the third landing on the moon.
On April 13th, at 54 hours into the flight,
Lovel and Haze were instructed to check out the lunar module
and televised their activities back to Houston.
However, none of the networks even bothered to broadcast it.
This is the crew of Apollo 15, guys.
Everybody there, a nice evening
and we're just about ready to close out our inspection of Aquarius
and good back for a pleasant evening at Odyssey.
Good night.
Mission Control noticed a slight pressure drop in one of the oxygen tanks
and instructed Swigert to turn on the heaters and stir the tank up.
Unknown to the crew at the time, an electrical short circuit sparked a fire in the oxygen tank's protective covering,
causing the tank to explode with such force that it blew a huge panel off the service module.
The explosion also ruptured the backup oxygen tank.
We've got a problem here.
Can I pay again, please?
Houston, we've had a problem.
And I heard a hissed bang.
The spacecraft rocked back and forth.
The jet started to fire to stabilize the spacecraft.
I looked up at Fred, and Fred looked down at me,
and I knew that Fred didn't know what caused his bang.
Then I looked over at our third companion, Jack Swigert.
He was over there in the left seat, and his eyes were as wide as saucer.

Our life support console and its operator noticed that we're beginning to see the pressure decrease in oxygen in the service module and for a time period we went through the normal steps to try to figure out what that situation might be.
was it some problem with instrumentation,
even though the crew had definitely heard something occur?
And more importantly, is it something where
the procedures we had could isolate that problem?
And we started seeing so many signatures.
There were all kinds of strange electrical signatures,
things in the fuel cells and all over
where it didn't match any of the kinds of symptoms
that we had been trained to look for.
And we felt that we really had run into another one of the
bizarre instrumentation phases.
Looking at the instruments that told me the condition
of two huge liquid oxygen tanks that we had way back in the service module,
on the quantity gauge of one, it read zero.
And on the quantity gauge of the other,
I could see the needle slowly go down.
Okay, Houston, I'm John. I tried to reset that fuel cell 1 and 3, both showing gray flags, but they're both showing zip on the flows.
Арnie Aldridge called me.
And the question and the dialogue was kind of like this between Arnie and I.
He says, John, there's been some kind of an anomaly here and the guys in the Mission
Control Team were chasing it because it seems to be a bunch of unrelated things.
it must be some kind of problem with the data relay of all the measurements from the spacecraft.
Initially, no one at mission control could believe that there was a complete structural
failure of the spacecraft, a situation that was never even simulated before.
It's so I asked him, I said, what are you reading some parameters? So I asked him to call up some
ECON displays and he read me some parameters and I said well read me some more and I said no
that's not, that's not an incantation failure. It may be missing more and I

what problem you're chasing out there but it's a real problem, it's not an
incantation problem. That problem is real. You have a real problem. Obviously I'll be
right there. I went past Jack, looked out the side window and I could see escaping
at a high rate of speed a gaseous substance from the rear end of my
spacecraft and very shortly we'd be completely out of oxygen and we'd be
completely out of electrical power and when that occurred because we gimbled
our maneuvering engine by means of electricity we would lose our
propulsion system what started out as a routine milk run to the moon was now
turning out to be the single greatest test of NASA's creative ability to solve
complex problems on a real-time scale to bring the crew back alive.
The mission was lost, and these astronauts were in a broken down spacecraft,
almost 200,000 miles from Earth, going in the wrong direction,
and had no idea how or if they were going to come home.
On the night of April 13th, I had just come into the control center
maybe half hour ahead of time.
And I was getting ready to go on shift.
My team was going on to the shift
takeover from Gene's team, Gene Kranz's team.
We needed time to think,
we needed time to establish a plan.
We needed time to figure out what was going wrong,
what had gone wrong, and then we needed time
to figure out what we were going to do about it.
Basically, the first activity we had was to buy time.
I think most of the team operated with confidence
that we were going to be able to pull it off, if it was salvageable at all.
I would have to say that probably each one of us in our own heart of hearts, at some
point during the events after the blow up and before we got stabilized, probably had
a little bit of a sinking feeling as to how this thing was going to turn out.
Some people at Mission Control wanted the spacecraft to turn around and return to Earth
immediately.
But Kranz and Lonnie argued that they couldn't depend on the spacecraft's propulsion system
and needed to build a rescue plan in the simulators.
I think there was a period in there when, I think very few people had any idea
how we would pull this off.
But I think the kind of training that we had, and the simulations, and the kind of people
we work with, that even though you don't know what the outcome is, um, you know you
probably don't have many opportunities to make mistakes.
Ben sitting in the room.

in my memory, as I recall it, it looked grim,
and we weren't going to make it.
Nobody ever anticipated that they were going to have a problem of this magnitude.
I mean, they had never simulated that many system failures.
I mean, the electrical system totally failed.
The oxygen system totally failed.
I mean, those kind of things weren't supposed to happen.
They had two oxygen tanks because if either one of them broke, the other one would work.
I mean, they only needed one of those tanks to make the whole trip.
But they carried two just to be safe, and suddenly they lost both of them.
I mean, like, nobody thought that was ever possible.
To where it didn't look good.

There was never any plans or even procedures to totally turn it completely off, dead, in

the very module that takes you there and gets you there.
Because it was a philosophical hurdle as well as a technical hurdle in this room.
With the command module as good as dead, mission control decided that their only option was
to move the crew into the lunar module.

objetient. The lunar module was small, cramped, and designed for only two crew members to

from the standpoint
was not so much that Given It Was Impossible,

And so a team was formed under Gene Kranz

What Gene did was to put John in the position of,

He had a lot of people.

In the hopes of stabilizing the water and power resources,
everything in the lunar module was shut down,
even the heaters and guidance controls.
All that could be left on was a small light, a fan,

It was clear that this problem was going to require the combined efforts
of every simulator engineer, systems analyst, backup astronaut, and computer technician.
They were all called into the NASA centers in the middle of the night of April 13th.
You know, they were worried if they were going to keep the life support systems going long enough to get them back.
And it was pretty shaky.
They didn't know if the heat shield was going to work.
I mean, after all, there had been this huge explosion.
And it could have damaged the heat shield easily.
And there's no way to test it.
You don't know until you actually do re-entry if it's going to work.
Since all of the systems of the spacecraft would have to be pushed beyond the outer limits of their specifications,

while most of america slept control rooms around the country hosted crews of bleary eyed technicians

people in bethpage in new york that built the

All of that got turned on. It was a team effort very across the country.
The first immediate challenge facing mission control was to change the trajectory of the
spacecraft using the lunar module engines.
In the case of Apollo 13, because of the landing site and the lighting conditions that were
desired, we actually diverted from the free return trajectory—that is, free return to
the earth after swinging around the moon—and we were on a trajectory which, had we not
done any more burns, would never have returned anywhere near the vicinity of the earth.
And we knew that we had to perform
some kind of a propulsion maneuver
with one of the rocket systems
in order to correct the trajectory
and get ourselves swinging around the moon,
but then coming back towards the Earth
approximately in an entry corridor.
After this burn put the spacecraft
on the correct flight path,
debates immediately began to rage in mission control.
The directors and management
split into two separate factions on just how quickly to bring the crew home. One group wanted
to jettison the useless service module to lighten the spacecraft and burn the lunar module's engine
at maximum as it rounded the far side of the moon, bringing the spacecraft back to Earth as soon as
possible. The other group argued if the service module was jettisoned, the command module's heat
shield would be exposed to at least four days of the ultimate cold of space. They pushed to leave
the service module attached and take a more conservative but longer return to Earth.
We had managers who listened to the technical inputs of the members of the team, and myself
and Lonnie and a couple of the other flight directors. Said, hey the way to do it is to take
the long road home because we have the confidence we can stretch the limb. And again, what we
have to do is we have to establish a strategy for coming home. We don't want to force ourselves
into decisions early in the game. We've got this limb spacecraft. We've learned how to use it as
a lifeboat. We ought to continue to use it out of lifeboat. We've got the ability to buy time.
